**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, the Court may modify a custody or parenting time order upon a showing of "a material and substantial change in circumstances" and consideration of the child's best interests.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28A, as Plaintiff and Defendant are the parents of the minor child and Massachusetts is the home state of the minor child.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue in Barnstable Probate and Family Court is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Defendant resides in Barnstable County.

**Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.proposition: The best interests of the child are paramount in custody determinations.
**Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C in terms of the child’s best interests and affirms the judgment based on a best-interests analysis. The court explicitly states that custody orders ‘are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child’ and that the judge must weigh all factors pertinent to those interests, confirming that the child’s best interests are the paramount standard in custody decisions.
**Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. See Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987); Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. at 925; Freedman v. Freedman, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 519, 522 (2000), and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.”}

**Braiman v. Braiman, 378 Mass. 86, 88 (.proposition: The best interests of the child are paramount in custody determinations.

**Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: A material change in a parent’s living situation (e.g., relocation) combined with negative impacts on the child may warrant modification of custody orders.
**Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct-appeal divorce/custody decision; it does not involve a post‑judgment modification of custody based on a material change in circumstances such as relocation. The court discusses initial custody allocation, joint vs. sole custody, and visitation, but nowhere addresses the legal standard for modifying an existing custody order due to a parent’s changed living situation or negative effects on the child. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition about modification of custody orders upon material change and adverse child impact.
**Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence… On this record we cannot say that the judge was clearly wrong in awarding sole custody to the wife.”

**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A material change in a parent’s living situation (e.g., relocation) combined with negative impacts on the child may warrant modification of custody orders.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The court explicitly rejects the idea that a custodial parent’s relocation, even with its impacts, is itself a material and substantial change justifying custody modification. The holding is that a request to relocate is distinct from a request to modify custody, and that modification must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move. Thus, the case stands for the opposite of the claimed proposition and cannot be cited to support it.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements… The judgment modifying custody must be reversed.”

**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Sleep deprivation, academic struggles, and stress caused by a custody arrangement are valid considerations in determining the child's best interests.
**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses best-interest factors in a removal context (school quality, transitions, housing, separation from family, impact on the custodial parent, etc.), but it does not mention sleep deprivation, academic struggles arising from a custody arrangement, or stress caused by a custody schedule as specific considerations. The single reference to an older child being at the bottom of his class appears only as background and is not analyzed as an effect of the custody arrangement or as a discrete best-interest factor. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.”

**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 844 (2.proposition: Courts must consider the practical feasibility of custody arrangements, particularly long commutes that interfere with the child’s school performance or wellbeing.
**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 844 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the statutory best-interests standard, the importance of preserving stable living arrangements, and the allocation of time between parents based on work schedules and caregiving roles. It does not discuss long commutes, school performance, or practical feasibility of custody arrangements in terms of travel burdens on the child. The only logistical considerations are relative daycare time and parental work flexibility, not commute length or its impact on the child’s wellbeing or schooling, so it does not establish the specific principle claimed.
**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 844 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Kali is to spend school weekdays with her mother because her mother’s schedule was sufficiently flexible to ensure that Kali’s needs during those periods will be attended to, and because that schedule would also provide ample opportunity for the mother and daughter to spend time together. To the same end, the order provides that Kali is to spend most school year weekends with her father, when he will not be constrained by long work days. The order splits summer and school vacations…”

**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495-96.proposition: Courts must consider the practical feasibility of custody arrangements, particularly long commutes that interfere with the child’s school performance or wellbeing.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495-96.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best-interests standard and geographic distance between parents, but it does not focus on, or require consideration of, the practical feasibility of specific custody arrangements such as long commutes or their direct impact on school performance or daily wellbeing. The court’s analysis centers on stability, parental alienation, and the parents’ relative availability and supportiveness, not on commute length or similar logistical burdens. Thus, the case does not clearly stand for the specific proposition about courts having to consider long commutes interfering with school or wellbeing.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495-96.relevant_excerpt: “Moreover, whether Jill is happy and well adjusted has no bearing on the judge’s decision concerning custody where neither parent asserts that the other is unfit; where the judge found that, unlike Rose, Hunter was able to put Jill’s needs above her own and ‘has managed to maintain a loving supportive relationship with [Jill] despite the distances’ between them; and where the judge was required to grant sole physical custody to one parent because of geographical distance that, in this case, was deliberately created by Rose.”

**Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Parenting schedules that disrupt sleep or school performance are contrary to the child’s best interests.
**Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns removal of children from the Commonwealth and the application of the Yannas/Mason removal standards. While the court briefly notes that the judge considered the impact of removal on the children and "deleterious effects of increased travel," it does not articulate or adopt any specific rule that parenting schedules that disrupt sleep or school performance are contrary to a child’s best interests. There is no discussion of sleep schedules, school performance, or a categorical best-interests principle tied to such disruptions, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
**Woodside v. Woodside, 79 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "The judge also considered the impact of removal on the children’s relationship with the father and the deleterious effects of increased travel, and adjusted the visitation schedule to increase the children’s time spent with the father during the weekends, summer, and other school vacations, as well as to limit the travel time between the parties’ homes."

**Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 882, 8.proposition: Massachusetts courts generally reconsider midweek parenting time when it imposes undue burdens based on a parental relocation.
